direction.raw_text: Behind the main title and the credits:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - A STUDY OF HOOFPRINTS - LATE AFTERNOON The hoofprints are deeply etched in the ground, picking their way through scrubby desert growth. An occasional tumbleweed drifts with the light breeze across the pattern of prints; and lightly-blown soil and sand begin the work of erasing them. The CAMERA FOLLOWING the hoofprints
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see the rider now. BACK TO CAMERA, jogging slowly along -- heading down a long valley toward a still-distant ranch house with its outlying barn and corrals.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The CAMERA FRAMES and MOVES with the lone horseman. He is ETHAN EDWARDS, a man as hard as the country he is crossing. Ethan is in his forties, with a three-day stubble of beard. Dust is caked in the lines of his face and powders his clothing. He wears a long Confederate overcoat, torn at one pocket, patched and clumsily stitched at the elbows. His trousers are a faded blue with an off-color stripe down the legs where once there had been the yellow stripes of the Yankee cavalry. His saddle is Mexican and across it he carries a folded serape in place of the Texas poncho... Rider and horse have come a long way. The CAMERA HOLDS and PANS the rider past and we see another detail; strapped onto his saddle roll is a sabre and scabbard with a gray silk sash wrapped around it... Horse and rider pass, moving closer to the ranch as a little girl and a small dog come tearing around the corner of the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She is staring wide-eyed at the distant horseman o.s. Her little dog has seen him too and is barking excitedly.
direction.name: direction

location: THE YARD OF THE EDWARDS RANCH
result.heading: EXT.

direction.raw_text: quickly reaches to grab the dog by the scruff of the neck, crouching over him. Debbie is 11 years old with a piquant, memorable face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here we must establish and dramatize what it is about her face that is memorable, so that if we were to see her again five or six years later, we would know it is she -- perhaps the eye color or the slant of eyebrow, or a trick of scratching bridge of nose with crooked forefinger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The ranch house is of adobe, solidly built, with a sod and cross-timbered roof, deep windows. A small gallery or porch extends across the front. AARON EDWARDS comes through the door, attracted by the dog's barking -- and then he, too, sees the approaching horseman and comes farther out -- curious but not at all apprehensive. Aaron is a lean, weathered and tired man, with a down-swept mustache; a gentler-looking man than Ethan and possibly a few years older. As he squints off, studying the rider, his older daughter, LUCY, comes out to stand behind him. Lucy is from 16 to 18 -- a pleasant, feminine girl. She is carrying a mixing bowl with some sort of batter in it, which she now completely forgets to whip in her interest in the approaching stranger. In the next instant MARTHA EDWARDS follows the daughter onto the porch. Martha is a still-lovely woman, although the years have etched fine wrinkles about her eyes and mouth, and work has worn and coarsened her hands. Those hands will never be idle when Martha is on scene... And now, while she shares the family's interest in the approaching horseman, she automatically notes that Lucy has forgotten her task -- and she takes the mixing bowl from her and stirs the batter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Along the side of the house comes BEN EDWARDS, 14, with a man-sized armload of chunkwood clutched to his chest. He, too, has spotted the stranger and is all attention. So much so that he trips, but recovers his footing. He pauses to dump the wood into a woodbox by the door -- his eyes always riveted on the oncoming rider -- and then he moves toward the others, biting a splinter out of a finger. Beyond Ben, MARTIN PAULEY emerges from the barn and crosses the open ground heading toward CAMERA. Martin is somewhat under 20, a lithe, perfectly coordinated male animal, with Indian-straight hair and a white man's eyes. He is carrying bridle or other horse-gear. He looks to the family on the porch -- to see if they recognize the stranger -- then out again. He continues, followed by Ben, toward where Debbie crouches over her dog.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As he rides downslope toward the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE SHOT - MARTHA, LUCY, AND AARON - LATE AFTERNOON Suddenly, Martha's eyes widen as she -- even before Aaron -- recognizes the distant rider. Her hand goes to her mouth to check the name that trembles on her lips... An instant later Aaron, too, identifies the oncoming horseman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks at her, frowning, then slowly steps out onto the hard ground. Martha hands the bowl back to Lucy and follows Aaron.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (incredulous) Ethan?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: as Ethan rides in and sits his horse, looking down at them. There is a noticeable constraint on all of them. Finally:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His eyes shift to Martha and hold. Ethan is, and always has been, in love with his brother's wife and she with him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ethan slowly, stiffly swings out of the saddle. Aaron and Martha exchange quick glances... troubled, puzzled. Aaron pastes on an uncertain smile as Ethan comes around his horse toward their side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He goes to his saddle pack, begins unlacing it. Ben and Debbie have inched closer -- half-shy, half-curious. Debbie's dog begins sniffing at his heels. Ethan looks down at them - not unfriendly, just a man not used to children.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ben nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ethan looks in the direction of the pointing finger.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: EXT.
location: THE YARD OF THE EDWARDS HOUSE

dialogue.raw_text: Hello, Aaron...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Martha...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a bit shakily) Hello, Ethan.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How's California?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How should I know?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But Mose Harper said...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That old goat still creakin' around?... Whyn't someone bury him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ben, ain't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (frowning at Debbie) Lucy, you ain't much bigger than when I saw you last.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm Deborah! (pointing) She's Lucy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: as Lucy steps down from the porch and approaches.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Lucy's going on seventeen now...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: An' she's got a beau! Kisses him, too!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's enough... Go on inside and help Lucy set the table... You, too, Deborah!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: as Martin -- with slightly averted face -- crosses to take the bridle of Ethan's horse and lead him away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Martin checks his stride, stares in surprise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Again, he starts to lead away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Martin stops again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He completes unlacing the pack and takes it -- treating it as though it contained something of value. Martin watches with a touch of resentment: Ethan doesn't trust him. Ethan turns and sees the look. He doesn't care what Martin thinks, nor does he explain. Martin leads the horse off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hesitates, then grudgingly surrenders it -- conscious of its sorry condition.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He just nods, then turns to follow Aaron around the side of the house toward the wash-up.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (wheeling on him)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (contritely) Martin!... Here we've been standing... Ethan, you haven't forgotten Martin?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh... Mistook you for a half-breed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (levelly) Not quite... Quarter Cherokee. The rest is Welsh... So they tell me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You've done a lot of growin'...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It was Ethan found you squallin' in a sage clump after your folks was massacred...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (bluntly) It just happened to be me... No need to make any more of it...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll take care of your horse for you, Uncle Ethan.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hold on!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll take this...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Supper'll be ready by the time you wash up... Let me take your coat for you, Ethan.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiling faintly) And... welcome home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: She stands alone, looking after Ethan -- his coat in her arms. She holds it against her breast for just a moment and her eyes are tender.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The family is finishing dinner -- and the scene is not quite, but almost, a still-life. Loud in the room is the pendulum tick of a Seth-Thomas clock on the mantel above the fireplace -- in which logs are burning briskly. Ben crouches near the fireplace, fascinatedly examining the scabbard and sabre Ethan has brought home from the wars. He tries to ease the blade just a bit out of its scabbard. Aaron sits at one end of the hand-hewn table, Martha at the other. At her right is Ethan, his fork scraping the last crumb off his plate. Lucy sits at her father's right and Martin at his left. Next to Martin is Debbie. In the center of the table is the sorry remnant of what was once a meal. Lucy and Martin have finished eating. Aaron is sipping his coffee, and Martha -- her own plate largely untasted -- is watching Ethan. Ethan has shaved, changed his shirt. He straightens contentedly and every eye is on him, expectantly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The clock rattles alarmingly -- the usual preliminary to its striking; and then it bangs out the strokes like a fire-alarm gong. Eight fast clangs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Martin nods and crosses to kiss Martha good night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ethan doesn't like being called Uncle -- as we must know from the quick look he shoots at Martin. But he acknowledges it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ben reluctantly puts the scabbard away, turns to Ethan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Ben reluctantly heads out with Martin, Deborah crosses to Ethan's side and studies him gravely.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ethan looks at her gravely.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He crosses to where his pack is -- a side table or something -- and burrows into it. Debbie is at his side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is a gold medal or medallion -- something appropriate to Maximilian of Mexico -- suspended by a long multi-colored satin ribbon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She holds it high for mother -- and all -- to see. Martha takes it and reacts at its weight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Martha reluctantly surrenders it to Debbie's eager hand. Aaron hasn't missed the word "Mexico" and looks sharply at Ethan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The two girls leave the main room. Martha and Aaron both look at Ethan -- half expecting some further explanation. He turns from them and looks into the fire. Martha begins to clear the table. Aaron gets up, takes a pipe and a spill -- lights it at the fire.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ethan turns and looks at her -- still busy with her dishes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Martha freezes in what she's doing -- listening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ethan can't answer, but he takes it as a challenge and almost welcomes it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Martha resumes her activity. Ethan crosses to his pack, reaches into it for a leather pouch, brings it back and tosses it onto the table. It lands with a resonant clink. Both Martha and Aaron draw close to the table. (NOTE TO WINTON HOCH: This scene should be dramatically back- lighted.)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He opens a waistline shirt button and hauls out a leather money belt and drops that on the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He reaches into the belt and takes out a few mint-fresh gold pieces which he slides across the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Martha picks up one of the gold pieces, staring at the face on the coin: the same as that on the medal -- staring sharply then at Ethan. Aaron is examining another coin with a different interest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He glances questioningly at Ethan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aaron shrugs and crosses to a barrel chair. He raises the seat and lifts out a pair of old boots, some rags of clothing and then raises a false-bottom lid and drops pouch and money belt into it. Carefully he replaces everything. During this Ethan's attention has gone to Martha's hand, to one cut finger, its wound barely healed. He takes the hand -- gently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She nods and withdraws the hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks quickly at him and self-consciously tries to hide her hands, conscious of their work-worn appearance. Then for a moment their eyes meet and hold -- and a world of sadness and hopelessness is in the look. Aaron closes the seat of the barrel chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He picks up one of the lamps and starts away toward their bedroom door. Martha looks at Ethan again. His expression is bitter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She turns obediently and follows Aaron. Ethan looks after them and waits as Aaron opens the bedroom door. Martha goes into it and Aaron follows and closes the door. Ethan crosses to the lamp on the mantel, blows it out. Only the firelight strikes his face as he stares broodingly at the closed bedroom door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ben! Deborah! Bed!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But I've got to help with the dishes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not tonight... Ben, put that sword back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's not a sword, ma... it's a saber! (moving to Ethan) Did you kill many damYankees with this sabre, Uncle Ethan?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (matter-of-factly) Some...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How many damYankees, Uncle Ethan?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ben!... Martin, he'll sleep in the bunkhouse with you tonight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good night, Aunt Martha... Uncle Aaron... (he hesitates) Good night, Uncle Ethan.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Will you tell me tomorrow about the war?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The war ended three years ago, boy!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It did?... Then whyn't you come home before now?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: !... Go 'long with Martin. MARCH!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (defensively) Well, it does... But I wouldn't care if you gave me a gold locket if it made my neck green or not.

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, thank you, Uncle Ethan...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Debbie) Come along...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They gave up... went back to the cotton rows... So'd the Jamisons... Without Martha, I don't know... She wouldn't let a man quit.

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (straightening -- with grave dignity) You're my brother... You're welcome to stay as long as you got a mind to... Ain't that so, Martha?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . YARD OF THE EDWARDS' HOUSE - FAINT DAWN LIGHT Debbie's dog is barking excitedly as six horsemen slowly ride toward the house and dismount. A lamp goes on inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a big man with frosty blue eyes, graying hair, a bristly full mustache and the air of grave and resolute authority. He is a minister of the Gospel with a .44 on his hip.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: the Edwards' neighbor, is a harried little man, Scandinavian. As we shall find out soon, he has a brisk and buxom wife and a rather astonishing brood of children.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is one of these: sandy-haired, brash, amiable, impulsive. He is in his early twenties.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: MacCORRY, slightly older than Brad, is Sergeant of Company A of the Rangers. (He is also Company A.) Charlie is a taciturn, gently-spoken, competent man, clearly patterned by his association with Captain, the Rev. Sam.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is an old scout -- a walking bone-rack, yet capable of tireless feats of endurance. Some think him "tetched" yet he has managed to endure to his age during a time and in a region where few men lived to see their grandchildren. He wears a ragged dark overcoat in all weather, a narrow-brimmed hat with a feather in its band.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is a rancher and homesteader in his mid-thirties; resolute, honest, self-effacing; nothing picturesque or dramatic about him; just a solid citizen and a realist.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EDWARDS' HOME - CLOSE SHOT - MARTHA She is at the window of her bedroom, wrapper clutched with one hand, lamp upraised in the other as she stares into the dawn to see who these callers are. We hear the heavy foot- falls of the approaching men, then a loud knock thrice repeated -- an ominous sound.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE EDWARDS' - ANGLE AT DOOR SAM'S VOICE Aaron! Open up!... Sam Clayton! The door is opened by Aaron -- holding a lamp and a gun. He is only partly dressed -- pants, boots, undershirt. The bar of light slashes across the faces of Sam and some of the men behind him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Reverend... Come in!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: CLAYTON Sorry to get you out of bed so early... (as Martha enters, tightening her wrapper) Mornin', Sister Edwards.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jorgensen enters -- an angry little man -- closely followed by Mose Harper, who is grinning foolishly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mose spots Martha and at once whips off his hat and makes her an exaggerated cavalier's bow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ed Nesby enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She heads for the stove.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His eyes brighten as he looks toward the fire and spots a rocking chair. He shuffles toward it, plants himself and begins rocking and half-crooning to himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The front door opens to admit Martin, fully dressed and armed, with Charlie MacCorry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Martin ranges himself next to Aaron and both face Clayton.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Martha sets out cups on the table, begins pouring the coffee. During the swearing-in, Ethan will enter the room from the inner door -- unnoticed by the other men, but not by Martha. And as the scene plays, the audience must always be conscious of the by-play of glances between Martha and Ethan as they face the prospect of being left in this house together.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But Ethan advances and calmly appropriates the cup Clayton is reaching for...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clayton marks his surprise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ethan sips his coffee and doesn't answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Martha has left the room briefly to fetch Aaron's shirt and vest and stands behind him. Aaron drains his cup.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ethan -- cup to his lips -- looks over its rim at Martha as Aaron starts to put on his shirt. Their eyes meet briefly, then she looks away. Ethan sloshes the dregs of his cup into the fire -- some of it spattering Mose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Martha stands submissively, with her head bent, eyes averted as Ethan crosses the room to get his coat, guns, etc. Aaron follows him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Martha waits -- intent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks past him then -- at Martha and then at Aaron.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks at Martha again... and then strides out.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What is it, Reverend?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lars Jorgensen claims someone bust into his corral last night and run off his best cows...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You mean those pure breds he just bought?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Next time I raise pigs, by golly! You never hear of anyone running off pigs, I bet you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Injuns has 'em... Caddoes or Kiowas... Kiowas or Caddoes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (irritably) Caddoes!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Respects to a charmin' lady, ma'am. ...Respects, respects...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mornin'...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Coffee's made if you...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Coffee'd be fine, sister...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (an old man's whimper) My bones is cold...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Or bumble bees, by golly... I show them dirty rustlers!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (crooning) Lookit me, old Mose Harper, rockin' in a rockin' chair... I'm a-goin' to set 'n rock, 'n rock, 'n rock, 'n rock...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Over here, Martin... Aaron...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Raise your right hands.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You are hereby volunteer privates in Company A of the Texas Rangers and will faithfully discharge the duties of same without recompense or monetary compensation -- meaning no pay!... Amen and get your shirt on, will you, Aaron.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (stubbornly) Ain't goin' volunteerin' after rustlers without my morning coffee, Reverend... Drink your own!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sternly -- as he reaches for his cup) From now on, call me 'Captain'!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (mockingly) Captain the Reverend Samuel Johnson Clayton!... Mighty impressive.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dourly) Well... the prodigal brother... When'd you get back?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Haven't seen you since the surrender. (a pause) Come to think of it, I didn't see you at the surrender.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't believe in surrenderin'... I still got my sabre, Reverend... never turned it into any ploughshare neither!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is no time for kaffee-klatch while a man's beef is been run off.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Injuns, Ethan... (taps his nose) Caddoes or Kiowas... Mose Harper, drinkin' coffee in a rockin' chair. ...ay-eh!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ethan, countin' on you to look after things while I'm gone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You ain't goin'...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He sure is goin'... He's sworn in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (angrily) Well, swear him out again!... I'll go with you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now, Ethan, I ain't sure...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't argue!... And stay close... Maybe they're rustlers... and maybe this dodderin' old idiot ain't so far wrong...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thankin' ye, Ethan... thankin' ye. Kind words...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (grudgingly) All right... I'll swear you in...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can forget that... (as Sam stares) Wouldn't be legal anyway.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why? (a pause -- then shrewdly) You wanted for a crime, Ethan?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You askin' as a Reverend or a Captain, Sam?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm askin' as a Ranger of the sovereign state of Texas.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Got a warrant?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You fit a lot of descriptions.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (levelly) I figger a man's only good for one oath at a time... I took mine to the Confederate States of America... (he pauses -- then) So did you, Reverend...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stick close, Aaron...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As Ethan emerges he is brought to a momentary halt by sight of a couple -- Brad and Lucy -- in each other's arms, standing near the saddled horses of the posse. Clayton and Jorgensen following him out, spot the couple, who now belatedly are conscious of their audience.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In confusion, Lucy runs back around the side of the house as Brad -- unrepentant -- grins at his irascible old man and heads for his waiting horse. Clayton chuckles and turns toward Martha, who has followed them out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mose, last to emerge, bows elaborately to Martha.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing moves. Nothing could be more tranquil. The shadows are long. A thin wisp of smoke rises from the chimney. And then Debbie's little dog trots around the side of the house out into the yard.

direction.raw_text: Debbie sits on the floor, playing with a little rag doll. The slanting blaze of the setting sun makes a brilliant area of light in which she is sitting. Beyond her, on the porch steps, Ben is squatting, whittling a piece of pine into a slingshot frame. We hear Martha and Lucy busy with the dishes. Aaron comes from behind CAMERA and stands in the doorway, absently rapping out his pipe. Near the doorway, on a wooden peg, hangs his gun, belt. He puts the pipe in his pocket and glances down at Deborah, intent on her play. He looks swiftly at where the women are busy - then stealthily eases the gun from its holster and slides it under his shirt. He hasn't made a sound and is sure he's got away with it. He clears his throat noisily and reaches for a light shotgun pegged above the door.

Ben takes a step as though to go to him, but Martha's hand at once is on his shoulder. Aaron gains the porch.

direction.raw_text: SHOT - THE POSSE - DUSK This should be an expansive view to convey the fact that the posse has split -- the main group heading for the Jorgensen place, Martin forking off to race alone for the Edwards ranch. Coming toward and passing CAMERA is Martin, riding all out. Several hundred yards away and moving in a divergent direction are the others -- Brad and Charlie, Sam, Jorgensen and Ed Nesby. The men are not compactly bunched, but strung out, each taking his own best course and his own speed... As the riders pass and the dust of their passing, we see two other riders -- Ethan and Mose -- minute specks in the distance, possibly a mile or two behind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (NOTE TO W. HOCH: What we are trying to get here is that moment of swift transition from twilight to night; of riders briefly touched with the last colors of day and then, as they pass, becoming one with blue shadows of night.) Ethan and Mose are holding their mounts to a jog, in marked contrast to the all-out pace of the others. The CAMERA PANS after them as the dark fingers of the night stretch across the valley. The wind begins to rise and somewhere off in the hills a coyote pack yaps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aaron is little more than a shadowy silhouette as he peers into the night through a partly-opened shutter. Suddenly the room leaps alight as Lucy opens an inner door and enters, holding a lighted lamp. Aaron closes the shutter, spins on her angrily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Martha crosses the room swiftly and blows out the lamp. In the brief moment the room has been lighted, we see that Lucy is carrying a dark shawl in one hand; that Ben is crouched at another window -- rifle ready; and that Deborah is on her feet -- standing like a child who is being dressed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He cautiously swings the shutters open. A pale light filters into the room. We see Martha wrapping the shawl around Deborah.

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The dog whines but obeys. Aaron continues watching the child's course -- unconsciously imitating her every run and twist... Then he smiles and we may see the brightness in the corners of his eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He closes the shutters and turns -- and his arms go around Martha, weeping soundlessly.
direction.name: direction

Then, with faintest little rustle, Debbie comes snaking along the ground into the hollow between the two graves and lies there face down, pressed against Topsy. She becomes one with the earth and the stillness. And then the moonlight strikes the tips of the scrub growth and as a cloud scuds by, the moonlight reveals something glittering -- like beads. And the CAMERA from that ground-level shot

direction.raw_text: - SCAR The Comanche we are later to know as SCAR is painted for war -- tall, savage, mockingly looking down at what we know is the child's hiding place... And in that instant, from a dozen quarters and a dozen throats, sounds the wild yammer of the warwhoop!

direction.raw_text: . RISING GROUND - MED. CLOSE SHOT - MARTIN - MOONLIGHT He stands beside his spent and fallen horse. Its breathing is a rasping whistle. Martin tries to haul its head up. Useless. Breathing hard himself, his face ashen in the moonlight, Martin looks desperately off in the direction of the ranch. Then he jerks the rifle from its saddle scabbard -- struggling with it because it is under the horse. He freezes then -- listening... And we hear the steady beat of two horsemen approaching. Martin knows who they are and his face is alive with hope. He gets the rifle free at last and goes running toward the oncoming riders.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The CAMERA SWINGS with him and we see Ethan and Mose approaching at the same steady gait.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ethan doesn't slacken, nearly rides him down.

direction.raw_text: Martin goes sprawling to his hands and knees. Mose continues without slowing.

direction.raw_text: (NOTE TO W. HOCH: Here again that use of red is suggested.) The ANGLE is past the porch uprights toward Mose and Ethan as they ride in. Little tongues of fire are licking the edges of the uprights. A few arrows, imbedded in the wood, are burning along their shafts. Beyond are the glowing ashes of the hayricks and the charred, smouldering rails of the corral. There are no bodies in evidence... The red glow of the burning is on the faces of the men as they dismount. Ethan strides to the porch, knocking away one of the blazing arrows as he heads to the door. He stops there -- and what he sees makes the big shoulders droop, the huge frame slump. Slowly then -- and removing his hat -- he goes in. Mose shuffles to the edge of the porch and squats there and rocks back and forth, his face working and crying soundlessly with senile grief. We hear a splintered door crash from its hinges within the room and Ethan's muffled voice calling through the house:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He strides back through the main room and out onto the porch just as Martin comes at a shambling run across the yard. Ethan takes a few steps out toward him. Martin would pass him, but Ethan grabs his arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Martin tries to fight his arm free.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ethan turns him and drives a brutal right to his jaw. Martin goes down -- out cold. And only now do we understand how merciful the blow was as Ethan looks compassionately at the fallen figure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And he takes off at a stumbling run for the hilltop.

direction.raw_text: - DAWN LIGHT The funeral is begun. In the foreground are three newly- made crosses at the head of as many open graves -- which we need not see. With head bared, Sam Clayton is concluding his prayer. Near him stand the Jorgensen family: Mrs.  Jorgensen, Lars and LAURIE -- blonde, just beginning to reach her maturity -- and a stepping-stone of tow-headed children.

dialogue.raw_text: . JORGENSEN (slowly) I almost hope they don't find them!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . OPEN COUNTRY - THE SEARCHERS - EARLY MORNING LIGHT The SEARCH THEME begins as we see the riders in turn. A series of portraits of the men.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - riding point, they come to a pause, surveying the terrain ahead. Charlie, with an arm signal, indicates he will take the left. Brad nods and he rides out to the right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clayton passing first, expression resolute, competent... Then Ed Nesby and old Mose, squinting at the ground as they ride, all but sniffing like an old hound dog.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: THE MAIN BODY OF THE MEN,

direction.raw_text: - Next to last in file. Finally:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - His face a study of relentless purpose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The two men are at a cairn of rocks -- their horses nearby. In the near distance, Clayton is leading the men of the search party at a fast clip toward the cairn. Charlie is standing, Brad tearing the rock cairn apart. In Charlie's hands is a Comanche head-dress of polished buffalo horn and feathers. Brad doesn't even look up as the men ride in and dismount, but continues his grim work of uncovering the buried Indian.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brad shifts another rock and Looks grimly upon the face (O.S.) of the dead Comanche. Then he spits at it and stands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With that he strides to the cairn, whipping a knife out. he crouches over the body (O.S.) concealing what he is doing, he bends to his bloody task. Sam Clayton crosses to stand behind him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He stands now and he faces Sam.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He flings the scalp down and grinds it into the dirt with his heel... He wipes clean the blade of his knife as he crosses back to his horse. The men mount (those who have dismounted) and they ride off.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Another one, eh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This 'un come a long way 'fore he died.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, that's seven we can score up to your brother, Ethan.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't like it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What don't you like?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Injun's on a raid generly hides their dead so you won't know how many they've lost... If they don't care about us knowin', it only spells one thing... they ain't afraid of us followin' -- or of us catchin' up with 'em either.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can back out any time, Nesby.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Didn't say that... (angrily indicating Brad) What's he doin' that for...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He wants to be sure...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (grim) Let's get along...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Brad) Why don't you finish the job?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (gravely) What good does that do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: By what you preach... none!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But by what the Comanche believe -- now he can't enter the spirit land, but has got to wander forever between the winds... because I took his mangy scalp!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT CAMP - RAVINE - CLOSE SHOT - BRAD AND MARTIN Brad is looking out into the night -- strain and tension in every line. Beyond them we may see some of the other men -- sitting or sprawled on the ground near a sheltered fire.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ethan crosses behind them carrying his blanket roll. He looks at them sourly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They move off, heading for their blankets. The CAMERA HOLDS on Ethan as he rolls up his blanket and turns on his side. He fishes a miniature out of his pocket and gravely studies it by the light of the flickering little fire.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (a whisper) If only she's alive... I'll make it up to her... No matter what's happened... I'll make her forget... She's just got to be alive...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Get some rest!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: It is a picture of Martha. The CAMERA PULLS BACK to show Ethan studying it gravely, then putting it away and lying back to stare broodingly into the night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The four faces are just over the ridge, peering at something far distant, far below.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He starts to squirm down the ridge, the others following.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Could be a buffler...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's horses, I tell ya...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's them all right...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Ethan's group crosses to where the other men are waiting with the horses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Martin and Brad stare at Sam -- not understanding the question. But Mose knows what he means and studiously looks into space.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They look into each other's eyes a moment, then Sam turns to mount... and the others follow. Slowly then they start riding down the slope.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: They're camped by the river -- 'bout twenty miles from here.  Soon's it gets dark we'll circle out so's to jump 'em before daybreak.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (slowly) You're right sure you want to jump 'em, Ethan?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (touch of defiance) It's what we're here for, ain't it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I thought we were trying to get the girls back -- alive... We jump those Comanches, they'll kill 'em... You know that!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (bewildered, angry) But... but what are we doin' then?... What are we supposed to do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What I had in mind was runnin' off their hoss herd... A Comanche on foot is more apt to be willin' to listen...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That makes sense to me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (angrily) What do you know about it?... What's a quarter-breed Cherokee know about the Comanche trick of sleeping with his best pony tied right beside him... You got as much chance of stampedin' their herd as...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...as you have of findin' those girls alive by ridin' into 'em...  I say we do it my way, Ethan... and that's an order!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, sir... But if you're wrong, Captain Clayton, don't ever give me another!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - DAWN MIST EFFECT (NOTE: It is now planned to shoot this on sound stage.) Fog and heavy morning mist rise from the swamp. Some cattails in the near ground. The effect is eerie, very still except for the trilling of frogs. Then, very quietly, the men emerge from the mist swirling around them. They are leading their horses. Sam looks baffled, angry. They stand still, listening -- then slowly continue.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - DAWN MIST (SOUND STAGE) The mist is thinning. In the f.g. is a small blackened area -- the ashes of a campfire. The men come through the mist -- wary, vigilant. It is Mose who first spots the fire. He runs to it and drops beside and feels the ashes. The others come up around him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks at Clayton.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They move on, slowly.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Ay-he... They was here...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Sam)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: !... They WERE here... Now they're out there... an' waitin' to jump us!...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You got any more orders, Captain?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quietly) Just keep goin'...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . FLAT GROUND - FULL SHOT - MOVING (SOUND STAGE) The mist is thinning as the men warily move along. Suddenly there is the faint hoot of an owl from behind and to one side... the men turn slightly, hearing it... A moment later another owl hoot, from the same side but up ahead. From the interchange of looks, we must know that the riders are aware of its significance. Mose cups hand to his mouth and he hoots in exact imitation of the other calls. Clayton glares at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ethan grins wryly. And now the first, faint, ruddy touch of the sun hits the slowly moving horsemen and begins to burn through the mist.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (in soft apology) Jus' bein' sociable, Cap'n...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . NEAR RIVER - PANNING SHOT - MORNING The CAMERA SLOWLY PANS from a sun-touched butte or crag to the file of men slowly walking their horses. An occasional shred of mist drifts by. Everything about the little cavalcade bespeaks tension, watchfulness. Suddenly -- and every man sees it at the same time -- we see a file of eight Comanches ride slowly out of a canyon at a distance, walking their horses at the same pace and on a course roughly parallel with, but slightly converging on, our group.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brad, who has been looking up ahead, sounds a new warning.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (softly) Keep goin'...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (tensely) Look!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Easy!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CANYON COUNTRY - LONG SHOT - PAST THE SEARCHERS Another Indian file of eight angles out of a different canyon and begins to cut in toward the group -- riding slowly, very quietly. Clayton slightly alters course, veering slightly away from the converging files, but still riding slowly. And then, from ahead but at a 100 yards, another Comanche group seems to rise out of the ground and slowly begins closing the gap.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And with that yell, he drives spurs and cuts sharply at an angle to the converging Indian files -- and every man is with him. In the next instant, the Comanches whoop and give chase.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to Clayton) If you were tryin' to surround 'em, you sure succeeded.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How far's the river from here, Mose?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I been baptized, Reverend... yes suh, been baptized, thank ye...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, you better brace yourself for another one... Ya-HEE!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . OPEN COUNTRY - FULL SHOT - THE CHASE with the Ranger group short-cutting in such a way as to outstrip the Comanche horsemen in a mad dash for the river.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE RIVER'S EDGE - FULL SHOT - THE GROUP Clayton flings his hand up in a signal to halt as the Rangers reach the bank. They rein in, wheel their horses and are reaching for the rifles as the Comanche vanguard races into view -- to find themselves opposed by seven veterans, sitting their horses, rifles at their shoulders. The charge breaks as the seven rifles bark, almost in unison -- and the Indians wheel to shelter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And once again he spins his mount and takes off, across the river, followed by the others.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE RIVER - FULL SHOT As the men pound across.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FAR BANK OF RIVER - FULL SHOT - THE GROUP They dismount and Charlie and Nesby take the horses and run them to some place of protection as the men group around Clayton and Ethan. During this:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mose runs over and crouches beside Ethan. Beyond Ethan is Martin, then Brad... Nesby and Charlie will rejoin the group after an appropriate interval... with all the men shielded behind river boulders, etc.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (shouting his orders) This is as good as any... Charlie, you and Ed take the horses...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Ethan and Mose are hunkered down behind some rocks, very casual and business-like as they check rifles, set out and carefully wipe cartridges.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Martin is in the throes of buck-fever, wiping mouth with back of his hand, peering anxiously across the river.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: EXT.
location: ANGLING PAST ETHAN AND MOSE WITH MARTIN AND BRAD BEYOND

dialogue.raw_text: (chattily) Minds me o' the time Joe Powers an' me fit us some Kiowas...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You think they mean to charge us, Uncle Ethan...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...We found us an ole buffler wallow...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (staring across river) Criminy!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: On the opposite bank, we see the full force of Comanches riding into sight -- racing their mounts to the edge, then wheeling off -- jeering, taunting. Brad starts to bring up his rifle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One Comanche rides a few yards into the water, brandishing his rifle, taunting the white men. A moment later he is joined by a second brave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He and Mose slowly bring their rifles to bear -- and then the two shots crack out almost simultaneously. And within split seconds both Comanches fall. The others race away. Sam comes charging over to Ethan and Mose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And he drops behind a rock as, with a wild whooping, the Comanche forces swing from their places of hiding and hit the river. The men open fire, all but Martin, who has frozen, staring wild-eyed at the oncoming Comanches.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Steady, Daniel Boone! You don't want to miss... It makes them think their medicine's stronger than yours...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ay-he... That's jest what I tole Joe Powers... That un's gettin' kinda sassy, ain't he, Ethan?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (grimly) Real sassy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (angrily) I didn't give any order to fire!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's all right, Captain... I don't need any formal invitation to kill a Comanch...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (grimly) You got one now!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Brad, Charlie, Clayton, Nesby are snapping shot after shot. Only Martin seems out of it. Ethan shoots him a glance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Some of the tension leaves Martin. Somehow his gun is in position and he is firing as fast and well as the others.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Slack your shoulders... Slack 'em... Your hands'll take care of themselves...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . THE RIVER - FULL SHOT - INDIAN CHARGE The Comanches are coming in, crouched low over their ponies' necks, whooping and firing. Men and horses go down, counted off by the expert marksmanship of the Texans. But they keep coming.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . RIVER'S EDGE - PROFILE SHOT - PAST MARTIN, ETHAN, MOSE They drop their rifles now and pull out revolvers for close- range work. One Comanche breaks through from the side, his buffalo lance ready for the thrust. Ethan whirls and fires. The Comanche horse charges through the defense line and out and there is a muffled scream of pain from Ed Nesby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE RIVER - WIDE ANGLE - THE INDIANS The charge breaks and Comanches wheel left and right, racing back across the river. With magnificent horsemanship, one brave rides to an unhorsed warrior crouched in the shallows and swings him up behind. Two others, riding together, head for one of the two dead Comanches Ethan and Mose had downed on their first shots. Swinging simultaneously from their saddles, they grab the dead man and carry him off.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: ANGLING PAST MOSE AND ETHAN MOSE

direction.raw_text: . THE RIVER'S EDGE - ANGLING PAST MOSE AND ETHAN MOSE (cackling) There goes yer scalp, Ethan!... Ethan snuggles his rifle to his shoulder as two other racing Comanches prepare to pick up the other dead Indian. Most of the Comanches have regained the far bank now and are racing away. The firing from the Texans has stopped.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I still got one out there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . RIVER'S EDGE - CLOSE SHOT - BEHIND ETHAN The angle is along his rifle barrel as it beads on one of the racing Comanches trying to pick up the dead Indian. Clayton's big hand grasps the rifle barrel.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (quietly) No, Ethan.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Ethan looks up into Clayton's face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ethan pulls the gun free and looks out across the river.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Let them bury their dead...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The Comanches have done their work, are riding away -- and over the saddle of one lies the limp form of the dead Indian. Ethan looks back at Sam.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The CAMERA SWINGS to pick up the figure of Nesby outstretched on the ground, writhing in pain; with Charlie kneeling beside him. The men cross to stand around the fallen man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ethan glares at them, but has to accept it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He heads away, for his horse. Brad and Martin look at each other as the full import of Ethan's footnote strikes home. Then they head for their own horses.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: That tears it, Reverend... From now on, you keep out... (mad now -- facing the others) All of you!... I don't want you with me... I don't need you... for what I got to do!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quietly) No need to shout, mister.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Reckon we got to go back -- Ed's shoulder is smashed -- bad!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can make it... just get me on a horse...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No good, Ed... And Ethan's right... This is a job for a company of Rangers... or it's a job for one or two men... Right now we're too many... an' not enough...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (facing Ethan) Only one way you can stop me lookin' for Lucy, mister... An' that's kill me...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's how I feel, Uncle Ethan... (correcting the slip) Ethan, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right... but I'm givin' the orders... You take 'em or we split up here and now...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quickly) Why, sure, Ethan... There's just the one thing we're after... finding Deborah and Lucy...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (grimly -- turning away) If they're still alive...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . THE RIVER - FULL SHOT Ethan, Martin, and Brad mount. Clayton crosses to them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They nod.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The three re-enter the river and slowly start across, with Clayton gravely looking after them. The three riders continue across the river... and the Search Theme resumes.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You boys got enough shells?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Vaya con dios.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . WIDE ANGLE - DESERT COUNTRY - BLAZING NOON A region of buttes and giant rock formations; treeless, arid and seemingly reaching out to infinity. Far off we see a cloud of dust -- miles and miles off. Only the dust, nothing else. From behind CAMERA ride the three men -- Ethan, Brad, and Martin -- dust-powdered, eyes bloodshot. The three are watching that distant cloud of dust. They force their weary horses onward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The ANGLE is past some spectacular butte or citadel of rock into another long reach of valley -- different from the first view of it, yet alike in its suggestion of endlessness. But now there is no cloud of dust far away -- nothing to suggest the passage of anything but time itself. Ethan, Martin, and Brad ride into the fringe of the butte's shadow and scan the terrain ahead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ethan turns to catch Martin thirstily drinking from his canteen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brad wheels on him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (shrill) They got to stop sometime... if they're human at all, they got to stop!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Naw... a human man rides a horse till it dies... then he goes on afoot... A Comanche comes along... gets that horse up... and rides it twenty more miles... Then he eats it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (angrily) Easy on that!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sorry... We don't even know if Debbie 'n Lucy are with this bunch... Maybe they split up...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're with 'em -- if they're still alive.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You've said that enough!... Maybe Lucy's dead... maybe they're both dead... but if I hear it from you again, I'll fight ya, Mr. Edwards!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (an aside) That'll be the day!... Let's ride.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . VALLEY AND CANYON WALL - WIDE ANGLE - THE RIDERS - LATE AFTERNOON (NOTE: This is the gap in the rocks near the "Medicine Country" at Monument.) The three riders come to where the trail they have been following forks... the main horseprint track leading ahead, a lesser track heading for a narrow gap between two buttes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ethan thinks he knows why. His face is bleak. But he tries to be casual.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns his mount toward the gap.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's still grumbling as he rides off. An abashed Martin rides ahead along the broad trail with Brad. (NOTE: Ethan's serape, tied behind his saddle, should be clearly seen as he rides away -- not pointed up, but visible.)
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Four of 'em cut out here... Why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll take a look... You keep after the others...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (eagerly) You want us to fire a shot if...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (disgustedly) No... nor build bonfires... nor beat drums neither. I'll meet you on the far side.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Martin and Brad, riding in a direction opposite to that in which they had taken off -- indicating their circle route -- haul up momentarily as they spot Ethan, standing beside his horse, his back to them, some distance along. They turn slightly off their course and ride out toward him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ethan turns, almost startled, as the two youths ride in. His serape is no longer behind his saddle. Ethan looks at them blankly for a minute -- as though not really seeing them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They both stare at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They both can see that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They look at him and each other -- for these are clearly unnecessary remarks and doubly surprising coming from Ethan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He goes to his horse, mounts. Martin is right beside him and he notes the missing serape.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He leads out. Brad rides up beside Martin. Again the two exchange puzzled looks. Martin shrugs and the three continue along the broad trace of the Indian ponies into the setting sun.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Oh... it's you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a vague gesture) I... uh... here's where they met up again...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pointing) Trail leads off there...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why'd they break off? (no answer) Was there water in that canyon?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Huh...?  No... no water.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You all right, Ethan?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Huh...? (more like his usual gruff self) Sure I'm all right...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Say!... What happened to your blanket? Lose it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Must've... Anyway, I ain't goin' back to look for it...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Ethan crouches over a small fire built into a slit trench so that barely the glow of the flames can be seen. Beyond him Martin is leading their unsaddled horses away. The men have come to the end of another long day. Both men look up as Brad comes over a hill slope and rides recklessly down the incline to their camp. His horse is lathered.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Martin runs to his side as Brad slides off his mount. Ethan moves more slowly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He can't look at Brad or at Martin. Brad can't speak -- and then finally:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ethan wheels on him in shouting fury.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brad wipes his mouth with the back of his hand. He turns -- walking stiff-legged as though on stilts back to his horse. He bends his head against the saddle, as though to hide his grief. Martin turns away from him and walks back to Ethan. And in that moment, Brad mounts and takes off in the same direction from which he had ridden in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They run for their horses.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (shouting it) I saw her!... I saw Lucy!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (continuing) They're camped 'bout two miles over... I was just swingin' back when I saw their smoke... I bellied up a ridge an' they was right below me...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you see Debbie?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, but I saw Lucy all right... She was wearin' that blue dress... an' she was walkin' along...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (voice flat) What you saw wasn't Lucy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It was, I tell you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What you saw was a buck wearin' Lucy's dress... (they stare at him) I found Lucy back there in that canyon... I wrapped her in my blanket an' buried her with m'own hands... I thought it best to keep it from you -- long as I could.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did they...? Was she...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (blazing) What've I got to do -- draw you a picture?... Spell it out?... Don't ever ask me!... Long as you live don't ever ask me more!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (frantically)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . ROUGH ROLLING COUNTRY - NIGHT - MOVING - CLOSE SHOT - BRAD He comes pounding down a slope, and he takes off his hat and skims it away. He rips off a neckerchief as though to relieve the rush of raging blood.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE EDGE OF A RISE - MED. CLOSE SHOT - BRAD - NIGHT He reaches the crest and reins in. A distant firelight is on his face. He takes one moment to look down into the Comanche camp o.s. Then he has his gun out. His eyes are wild, his face wet with sweat. Then he throws back his head and he yells -- and with the yell goes charging into the camp.
direction.name: direction

PLAINS COUNTRY - LOW ANGLE SHOT - DAY A study of horseprints etched in the soil -- the mark of the passage of many horses; perhaps an eagle or turkey feather fallen from a warbonnet. And then we hear and see the approach of two plodding horses, and the dusty boots of the horsemen -- Ethan and Martin -- following the trail. The Search Theme resumes and continues over the next three shots, helping us suggest the passage of time, the change of scene.

direction.raw_text: . PLAINS COUNTRY - LOW ANGLE SHOT - ETHAN AND MARTIN - AFTERNOON It is a portrait study of two faces -- etched by wind and privation and cold into tragic, fanatic masks. Martin has aged years in a matter of months. Falling snow flakes touch their faces and begin to rime their stubbly beards.

direction.raw_text: . THE JORGENSEN HOUSE AND APPROACH - WIDE ANGLE - TWILIGHT The time is spring. It is a year and a half later. The Jorgensen house is larger than the Edwards place -- of sod and logs, with a covered breezeway connecting the two separate buildings of the house: one being the keeping room, the other the sleeping quarters of the numerous Jorgensen brood. A meadowlark breaks into his sudden song. A dog or two come barking around the side of the house as Ethan and Martin ride slowly from behind CAMERA toward the house. In that instant a lamp is lighted within the house and Lars Jorgensen comes to the door.

They are thinking of Brad -- dead because of their search; and Martin is thinking of Laurie. And then Mrs. Jorgensen is running across to Martin and has him in her arms as though he were her son -- saying nothing, just holding him. He stands frozen a moment and then he returns the embrace. There should be Scandinavian accents in the decor. All told, a cheerful, warm-smelling room. Ethan is talking as Laurie enters the room still carrying Martin's shirt, the rags of his underwear. She will wait, listening for a break in what Ethan is saying, to try to get her mother's attention. Jorgensen is sitting in his usual chair -- with his boots off, puffing his pipe more or less in tune with what Ethan is talking about. Mrs. Jorgensen is in her rocker, darning or knitting. direction.raw_text: Martin is a bit surprised as Ethan takes the blanket and spreads it near the saddle -- making the saddle serve as a pillow. Then Ethan tosses a few more heavy pieces of dry wood on the fire, making it blaze up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He spreads his own blanket as Martin wraps into his bedroll, and when Martin turns, he casually arranges the blanket to suggest it is over the figure of a man. During this:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ethan steps back -- and studies the "dummy."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ethan studies Martin's back -- the light on him -- and looks around figuring the range of fire.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Martin just grunts and snugs deeper into his blanket. Ethan nods his satisfaction -- sure Martin isn't going to change positions. Then he takes off his hat and boots and uses them to complete the dummy. He picks up his rifle then and quietly walks out of the camp.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Wouldn't surprise me if we didn't have a frost 'fore mornin'... Here... (he picks up a saddle and puts it close to fire) Whyn't you bed down closer to the fire, boy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey! What's the idea...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe I'm gettin' like Mose Harper -- my bones is cold tonight...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Funny... When we passed through Fort Wingate last winter, we didn't hear mention of any Nawyecky Comanche there...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not so funny... if you recollect what 'Nawyecka' means...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sorta like 'roundabout' -- like a man says he's goin' one place when he means to go just the reverse...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (drowsily) Oh...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You all settled an' comfortable now?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Three shadowy figures -- Futterman and his two henchmen -- are quietly dismounting, taking rifles from saddle scabbards. At a hand signal from Futterman, they quietly fan out afoot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE SHOT - MARTIN still snug in his blankets, sound asleep; the fire burning a little lower but still shedding plenty of light on him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At a crouch or crawling, the three worm their way among some rocks until they reach a slight rise looking down into the camp. Martin is asleep and next to him is Ethan's dummy, hat over its face, and the fire still burning. The two henchmen snake their rifles up to a firing position. A shot cracks... and one man is knocked flat on his face. The other whirls in the direction of the shot, his rifle swinging in search of a target. A second shot splits the night and the breed falls as though hit by a giant fist... Martin is sitting up now, staring wildly around. Futterman starts to run down-slope, away from the hidden marksman, dodging between the rocks. A third shot catches him in the back and he spins and falls and rolls down the slope into the firepit camp area. Martin is on his feet now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is staring at Futterman, face down and almost at his feet. He looks around in fear at someone approaching -- hand going to his gun. Then he relaxes as Ethan casually enters the camp, bareheaded, carrying his rifle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ethan kneels beside Futterman, turns him over, reaches into his pockets -- first one, then another.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ethan grins satisfiedly as he straightens and spins the gold piece in the air, catches it and pockets it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And now Martin is getting the whole picture... and he's mad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ethan is just grinning at him -- completely unruffled, denying none of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ethan sobers a little, seems honestly surprised.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks... you did just fine...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dazed) Futterman?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He just couldn't wait...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (watching him go through pockets) Whatchu doin'?...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Even got my twenty dollars back... We did all right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ?... You just used me for bait -- staked me out like a... buildin' up the fire... fixin' it so's... I coulda had my brains blowed out!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (explosively) Suppose you'd missed!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Never occurred to me...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . THE JORGENSEN HOME - WIDE ANGLE - DAY It is a day in early winter. Charlie MacCorry, short-coated, is galloping across the yard as Jorgensen crosses it -- carrying a load of firewood.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: MacCorry swings off his saddle near the porch, as the door opens and Mrs. Jorgensen comes out -- shawled against the cold.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jorgensen lets the cordwood drop...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (calling it) Howdy, Mister Jorgensen...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Charlie...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Got a letter here...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: By golly! A letter?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: For Miss Laurie...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . JORGENSEN Come in, Charlie, come in... (calling inside)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: !... My land!... Two letters in the one year!...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: as Charlie enters, following Mrs. Jorgensen. Jorgensen excitedly enters and closes the door. Laurie comes in from another room. Charlie smiles and bows clumsily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hands the letter to Laurie who comes over eagerly, takes it and studies the wrapper before opening it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But Laurie has no interest in anything but the letter which she is reading skimmingly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Laurie looks up then.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs. Jorgensen has been pulling and pushing chairs around and now they all take places. Jorgensen automatically reaches for his glasses on the mantel and puts them on -- even though he isn't going to read the letter. Laurie has been sneaking looks at some of the other pages.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She breaks off, looks up -- puzzled.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . JORGENSEN (to Laurie) A letter for you, Laurie...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes'm... Figgered it might be the news you been waitin' for... so...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . JORGENSEN Real good o' you to ride all the way over, Charlie... Might at least say your thank you's, Laurie... Declare!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No need to...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . JORGENSEN Well?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (expectantly) Yah?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . JORGENSEN Laurie! Don't keep a body just standin'!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (impatiently) I was just readin' to see if... Anyway, it's MY letter!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . JORGENSEN (agreeably) 'Course it is. Now let's all get comfortable an' set so's we can listen while Laurie reads her letter...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (turning as if to go) Maybe I'd better be goin'...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You stay, Charlie... After all, Charlie brought the letter, Laurie... He got a right to listen too!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (surrendering) Oh, all right!  Well... Martin says...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: From the beginning...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: 'Dear Miss Laury'... He spells it with a Y instead of an I... E... Wouldn't you think he'd know...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who cares what he spells it? Read the letter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dear Miss Laury... I take pen in hand to let you know Ethan and me still are trying to catch up with them Comanches the late Mister Futterman told us about...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The late Mister Futterman?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That means Mister Futterman is dead, by golly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . JORGENSEN Wonder what happened to the poor man.  Go on, Laurie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (resuming the letter) We cut north through Indian territory and... (her voice fades)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: LATE SUMMER OR FALL - ETHAN AND MARTIN (SILENT) leading their pack animals. Martin's voice picks up the narration.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Soon we was meeting up with Kiowas an' Wichitas an' even some Comanches camped by one of the agencies...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - ETHAN AND MARTIN - DAY FALL WEATHER (SILENT) The camp is on the outskirts of a trading post. Indians watch unsmilingly from tepees, or in little clusters afoot; a few mounted braves ride on parallel courses as Ethan and Martin ride through camp toward the post.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: But none of them was Nawyecky's nor claimed to know a war chief named Scar... He's the one the late Mister Futterman said had Debbie...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: This trading post is in marked contrast to Futterman's -- being well-stocked, clean and presided over by HIRAM APPLEBY, a resolute, clean-looking man of middle years. Ethan and Martin -- in winter garb -- are being shown a variety of trade goods, including a shoebox full of ornate ribbon rosettes, such as are awarded animals at stock fairs. Appleby is solemnly affirming the trade value of these, as well as sleeve garters, etc.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: At one o' the agencies we outfitted with all kind an' manner of trade goods... figgerin' that'd make it easier for us to come an' go... You'd laugh if I told you what was our biggest seller...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE SHOT - ETHAN AND FAT INDIAN - EARLY WINTER OR FALL DAY Ethan is ceremoniously pinning something on the stern-faced buck. It is one of the rosettes seen in the shoebox.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: to an extreme CLOSEUP of the rosette. On it, in gold letters, is:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . INDIAN ENCAMPMENT - FULL SHOT - EARLY FALL OR WINTER DAY As the Indian proudly steps back, we see beyond him a half dozen other braves -- all rosetted. Ethan looks them over complacently while Martin -- to hide the smile that threatens to split his face -- bends to pick up a huge bundle of furs.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: FIRST AWARD LARD TYPE HOG EXT

direction.raw_text: reading the letter. She is at the bottom of a page.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She stops and stares.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks at them - dazed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs. Jorgensen, full of sympathy for Laurie, just glares at her husband.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And with that she crumples the letter and throws it into the fire.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jorgensen is out of his chair and scrambling in the fireplace to recover the letter. He fetches it out, beating the sparks out. The letter is basically undamaged.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Laurie snatches the letter back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charlie crosses the room, picks up a guitar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Laurie glares at him. He begins chording the guitar.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: 'There is one other thing I got to tell you before you hear it from Ethan... How I got myself a wife'...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (delightedly) He did?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smacking his knee -- very happy indeed) Good! A young man should get married early in life. Right, mama?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Every young man should at least once...Go on, Laurie! Read!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (haltingly) A little Comanche squaw - SQUAW!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . JORGENSEN (aghast) Laurie!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sternly) Is no way to treat a letter, Laurie ...Mama maybe you better read it... (to Charlie, proudly) My wife was a school teacher, Charlie ...She reads good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll read it...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smugly) So he married a Comanche squaw... Haw haw haw!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE SHOT - MARTIN AND "LOOK" - FALL OR EARLY WINTER - DAY "LOOK" is somewhat under five feet tall, pigeon-toed, platter- faced and wide-eyed. Over her arm is a very handsome blanket. She is coming forward shyly toward Martin, propelled by a Comanche -- her father. Martin, with an armful of trade goods -- a few yards of bright calico, a couple of AGED SOW rosettes and some trinkets -- is indicating the blanket. Look glances shyly at her father. He shakes his head negatively. Look is disappointed. The father points to Martin's pile of trade goods. Martin bends and picks up the indicated object: it is a battered high-crowned beaver hat. The Indian grunts his approval and puts it on. Look looks relieved. Martin reaches for the blanket. Look takes a quick step backward and holds up one finger: wait! Then she runs back through the other Comanches now crowding forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - INCLUDING ETHAN who rides in slowly, leading their pack horse and Martin's horse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The name registers with some of the nearer braves. There is a quick interchange of glances, frowning, hostile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Martin mounts and the two ride out. The Comanches stare after them suspiciously, resentfully.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (quietly) Let's go... I think I stumbled onto somethin'...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (eagerly) Scar?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (angrily) When are you goin' to learn to keep your mouth shut! Come on.  Let's get out of here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But I just bought a good blanket.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (curtly) Forget it...
dialogue.name: dialogue
